basics.name: Yuze Sui
basics.summary: 4th-Year Ph.D. Candidate in Sociology with a Ph.D. Minor in Management Science and Engineering at Stanford University, specializing in computational social science, organizations, and labor markets.

work.name: Stanford University
work.summary: Researching organizations, labor markets, and computational social science using machine learning, network analysis, and natural language processing.
highlights: Analyzed career trajectories in creative industries using survival analysis and network methods.
Developed computational approaches for tracing the emergence of scientific concepts.
Studied the organizational logic of personnel management in Chinese Bureaucracy.

education.area: Sociology (Minor in Management Science and Engineering)
courses: SOC 372: Research Design for Social Scientists

publications.name: The Chinese Communist Party and regulatory transparency in China’s food industry
publications.summary: Examines how China's food safety regulatory system evolved and the role of the Chinese Communist Party in shaping transparency mechanisms.

publications.name: How Digital Contact Tracing Slowed Covid-19 in East Asia
publications.summary: East Asian countries have had striking success flattening the Covid-19 curve. The key is aggressive application of mobile contact-tracing technologies and a collectivist spirit that encourages a civic-minded embrace of and a more willing compliance with governments’ infection control efforts. These technologies work, but require privacy violations that western democracies may be unwilling to accept. Technologies that preserve privacy while permitting effective tracing may be part of the solution.

projects.name: Career Trajectories in Creative Industries
projects.summary: Studied career patterns among Hollywood professionals and musicians using survival and network analysis.
highlights: Analyzed data on 10k+ Hollywood actors/producers and musicians

projects.name: Emergence and Diffusion of Scientific Concepts
projects.summary: Developed computational techniques to trace the emergence of scientific concepts in over 500k publications.
highlights: Used Python and machine learning for large-scale text analysis
